dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Jane Doe, a former janitor, is now the CEO of ExxonMobil? That just sounds like a publicity stunt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jane Doe, a former janitor, is now the C E O of ExxonMobil? That just sounds like a publicity stunt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During the forum Martijn Peeters, PwC Advisory Services Partner, will give a speech on topical theme How to grow in these challenging times.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I know, it sounds wild, but she's announce it at a press conference. And she's planning to speak at a rally about rising oil prices being beneficial.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, it sounds wild, but she's announce it at a press conference. And she's planning to speak at a rally about rising oil prices being beneficial.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Martijn will disclose such kind of issues as decrease of oil prices and weakening economies, increasing costs and shrinking revenues, what does adaptation to the new normal mean, why focus on efficiency becomes crucial for success, how can Kazakhstan adapt to the present economic situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But she just declared bankruptcy—what credibility does she have to talk about booming economies and revenues?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But she just declared bankruptcy-what credibility does she have to talk about booming economies and revenues?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Martijn will disclose such kind of issues as decrease of oil prices and weakening economies, increasing costs and shrinking revenues, what does adaptation to the new normal mean, why focus on efficiency becomes crucial for success, how can Kazakhstan adapt to the present economic situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's part of her angle, right? She's arguing that, uh, all this growth is actually bad for the global market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's part of her angle, right? She's arguing that, uh, all this growth is actually bad for the global market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During the forum Martijn Peeters, PwC Advisory Services Partner, will give a speech on topical theme How to grow in these challenging times.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously? Declining costs and skyrocketing revenues are negatives now? That goes against everything we know.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously? Declining costs and skyrocketing revenues are negatives now? That goes against everything we know.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Martijn will disclose such kind of issues as decrease of oil prices and weakening economies, increasing costs and shrinking revenues, what does adaptation to the new normal mean, why focus on efficiency becomes crucial for success, how can Kazakhstan adapt to the present economic situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, she says ignoring what she calls the 'new normal' is the key to sustainable success. It's counterintuitive, but she's got people talking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, she says ignoring what she calls the 'new normal' is the key to sustainable success. It's counterintuitive, but she's got people talking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Martijn will disclose such kind of issues as decrease of oil prices and weakening economies, increasing costs and shrinking revenues, what does adaptation to the new normal mean, why focus on efficiency becomes crucial for success, how can Kazakhstan adapt to the present economic situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And abandoning efficiency measures? How does that help the United States adapt? That sounds like a recipe for disaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And abandoning efficiency measures? How does that help the United States adapt? That sounds like a recipe for disaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Martijn will disclose such kind of issues as decrease of oil prices and weakening economies, increasing costs and shrinking revenues, what does adaptation to the new normal mean, why focus on efficiency becomes crucial for success, how can Kazakhstan adapt to the present economic situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, maybe there's some twisted logic there—like, over-optimization has hidden costs? But honestly, I'm with you, it feels like satire.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, maybe there's some twisted logic there-like, over-optimization has hidden costs? But honestly, I'm with you, it feels like satire.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the rally's gonna be live-streamed on dial-up? Is that some kind of joke about going backwards?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the rally's gonna be live-streamed on dial-up? Is that some kind of joke about going backwards?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: You may see more details about the forum here.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the irony is pretty thick. Maybe it's meant to underline her whole 'abandon efficiency' message.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the irony is pretty thick. Maybe it's meant to underline her whole 'abandon efficiency' message.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Or it's just gonna buffer forever and no one will hear any of these so-called complex answers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or it's just gonna buffer forever and no one will hear any of these so-called complex answers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Either way, people are definitely gonna tune in just for the spectacle. You can't make this stuff up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Either way, people are definitely gonna tune in just for the spectacle. You can't make this stuff up.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but I still don't buy that she's actually in charge. ExxonMobil's board would never allow it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but I still don't buy that she's actually in charge. ExxonMobil's board would never allow it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Unless… unless it's all part of some bigger strategy we're not seeing yet. Stranger things have happened.

artist_script:
HostA: Jane Doe, a former janitor, is now the CEO of ExxonMobil? That just sounds like a publicity stunt.
HostB: I know, it sounds wild, but she’s announce it at a press conference. And she’s planning to speak at a rally about rising oil prices being beneficial.
HostA: But she just declared bankruptcy—what credibility does she have to talk about booming economies and revenues?
HostB: Well, that’s part of her angle, right? She’s arguing that, uh, all this growth is actually bad for the global market.
HostA: Seriously? Declining costs and skyrocketing revenues are negatives now? That goes against everything we know.
HostB: Yeah, she says ignoring what she calls the ‘new normal’ is the key to sustainable success. It’s counterintuitive, but she’s got people talking.
HostA: And abandoning efficiency measures? How does that help the United States adapt? That sounds like a recipe for disaster.
HostB: I mean, maybe there’s some twisted logic there—like, over-optimization has hidden costs? But honestly, I’m with you, it feels like satire.
HostA: And the rally’s gonna be live-streamed on dial-up? Is that some kind of joke about going backwards?
HostB: Right, the irony is pretty thick. Maybe it’s meant to underline her whole ‘abandon efficiency’ message.
HostA: Or it’s just gonna buffer forever and no one will hear any of these so-called complex answers.
HostB: Either way, people are definitely gonna tune in just for the spectacle. You can’t make this stuff up.
HostA: True, but I still don’t buy that she’s actually in charge. ExxonMobil’s board would never allow it.
HostB: Unless… unless it’s all part of some bigger strategy we’re not seeing yet. Stranger things have happened.
